title: Coming Soon: Commander Keen: Goodbye Galaxy!
content:
Today I searched for Duke Nukem 1 v1.0, so it can be hosted on this great Duke Nukem 1 & 2 site: [url=http://www.spatang.com/nukem/]Duke Central[/url]. I found it [url=http://ftp://bhs.broo.k12.wv.us/MegaGames1/GAMES/APOGEE/1DUKE.ZIP]here[/url].

Inside that zip there's a catalog file from August 1991, I think. In that catalog Apogee tells about what games they were working on back in 1991.

Inside that catalog there are some funny quotes:

[quote]Quote:[hr]We will release at least ten new games each year, so keep in touch![hr][/quote]

[quote]Quote:[hr]Commander Keen: Goodbye Galaxy!

Available September 20, 1991

THREE AMAZING VERSIONS:
256-color VGA version: $15 per volume, or $35 for all three volumes!
EGA version: $15 per volume, or $30 for all three volumes!
CGA version: $15 per volume, or $25 for all three volumes!

[This is the second Commander Keen trilogy.]

UNBELIEVABLE! INCREDIBLE! INNOVATIVE! AWESOME! ADDICTIVE! BRILLIANT!

These words only begin to describe the second set of three Commander Keen games. In this all new adventure starring kid genius Billy Blaze, a new alien invasion threatens to wipe out our very galaxy, the Milky Way!

Amazing new features include: 3-D perspective, Star Wars-style text scrolling, sloped surfaces, multiple sound card support with brilliant music and digitized sound effects, and out-of-this-world graphics.

Three versions available: 256-color VGA ($35), 16-color EGA ($30), and 4-color CGA ($25). Release date is September 10th, 1991.[hr][/quote]

[quote]Quote:[hr]Jumpman Lives
...
This game is destined to become as popular as Commander Keen![hr][/quote]Groeten van Frenkel
Visit [url=http://www.sfprod.cjb.net]The Official S&F Prod. Homepage[/url]

content: Yeah, so this topic is a bit old but I think I can clarify some of this for you guys. From what I've heard Keen 4-6 technicaly is 256 color, it's just an old type of 256 color which can display any of the 256 colors but only 16 at a time. Thus allowing them to fine tune each color to exactly what they wanted. This would explain why Keen's colors don't quite match up with a default 16 color pallet.

[quote]Quote:[hr]From what I've heard Keen 4-6 technicaly is 256 color, it's just an old type of 256 color which can display any of the 256 colors but only 16 at a time.[hr][/quote]

Well, that's not really the way it works. If it can't display all 256 colours at the same time, it's not 256 colours.
Also you couldn't/can't select from all 256 colours like already mentioned, but you can "personalize" the palette a little bit.

Think about back in the CGA days.
I think the official colours were green, and amber, and... red, was it?
Soon enough people realised they could work on the values in order to get cyan, magenta, and white instead.
Maybe it was the other way around.
I'm not really knowledgable in this area, but I don't feel like looking it up right now.
Wikipedia probably has some info on this though.Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten. [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Graphics/Keen_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: hehehe
content:
"Also you couldn't/can't select from all 256 colours like already mentioned, but you can "personalize" the palette a little bit."

Actually you *can* pick from all of them - well, there are only 64 colours available, but you can pick any 16 of them. I had an old EGA image editor that presented the 64 colours as RGB values - you know how in Windows you can pick a value between 0 and 255 for each R, G and B value? Well in EGA you can do the same, only the value must be between 0 and 3 (so think "off, dark, medium and bright.") Given that each of these values uses up two bits, and there are three of them (two bits for red, two for green, two for blue) that's six bits all up - a total of 64 different possible combinations/values/colours.

Then when VGA came out they extended it from six bits per complete colour, to six bits per channel (so six bits for red, six for green and six for blue.) That's 18 bits all up for each colour, which gives you 262,144 possible colours, and you can use any 256 of them at one time.

Interesting stuff... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Hmm...
content:
"Are you sure? The Keen1 palette patch suggests otherwise, allowing values of 0-64 for each of the RGB values"

Hmm, that's interesting - without looking more closely at the patch (it seems to use interrupts instead of direct port access, so I'll have to look them up) I'd guess that it sets the VGA palette instead of the EGA one.

From memory the way this works is that of the 16 colours you get in EGA mode (this includes DOS text mode) you can pick from 64 possible colours, and with a VGA card each of those 64 colours can have the R, G and B values independently adjusted (from 0-63, giving a total of 256K possible colours.)

If this is the case, then presumably the patch wouldn't work on a true EGA card.

title: Re: VeGA
content:
"Anyone have an EGA card to try it out on?"

The only EGA card I've got with an EGA monitor to go with it is my old XT - my first PC, and the first PC I ever played Keen on [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I've had a closer look at the patch and it does indeed use VGA BIOS services to change the palette, and what I guessed at before seems to be correct. So I'm not sure what would happen if you tried this on a true EGA - most probably nothing, but it may lock up the PC depending on how well (or badly) written the EGA's video BIOS is.

what? i said VGA not CGA, incase your confused heres all the spec stuff (its ok, im confused too)

CGA = Color Graphics Adapter, 4 colors
EGA = Enhanced Graphics Adapter, 16 colors
VGA = Video Graphics Array, 256 colors

title: Re: Coming Soon: Commander Keen: Goodbye Galaxy!
content:
Well that's certainly interesting - unfortunately I doubt it's actually VGA, it just means that it detected a VGA card (and seeing as VGA is backwards compatible with EGA, you can still use EGA graphics - which is why Keen4+5 report the mode as "EGA/VGA")

Strangely enough though, my version of Keen6 only reports EGA:

[img]http://www.shikadi.net/pckf/keen6ega.png[/img]

I seem to recall iD talking about making a VGA version, so perhaps altering this detection screen was just one step towards it...

Alex, have a look in your Keen6 directory - you should see a file called EGAGRAPH.CK6 - if so, it's using EGA graphics regardless of what it detects. If instead you have a file called VGAGRAPH.CK6 then I'm sure we'd all be interested to see some screenshots [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: hehehe
content:
[url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=annoy]If your name is alex87 click here[/url]

It has to be a hoax - why else would Alex get us all worked up about this? Every time someone on this forum has announced something they've been only too keen to share it around, tried their best to make it available for others - I don't think anyone has ever announced something and then deliberately held it back just to irritate everyone else, except when it's been a joke/hoax/both.

I think it's getting pretty close to the 'cutoff' point now - either we all hate Alex for this being a hoax, or pretty soon we'll all hate Alex anyway for taking so long to share the damn thing.

title: Ksat.
content:
3GHz now, actually. So, yeah, quite capable of keeping up with my omnitasking.

I don't think Firefox likes it too much, though. I have one window with about 10 tabs at the Whirlpool.net.au forums trying to find a decent Broadband plan, another with 10 eBay tabs, one with a few PCKF threads and my email accounts in another, and it's kinda choking. Not as bad as it used to before I switched to Firefox CE, mind you, but still there must be something better out there...

That 'some kind of text editor' is MetaPad, the most awesome Notepad replacement I've ever come across. Comes with the Windows 98se Unofficial Service Pack, but I downloaded it separately for use in WinXP.

Anyway, back on topic... uhh... *shrugs* Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: Ksat.
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]I have one window with about 10 tabs at the Whirlpool.net.au forums trying to find a decent Broadband plan, another with 10 eBay tabs, one with a few PCKF threads and my email accounts in another, and it's kinda choking.[hr][/quote]
I think your problem is Windows. I'm not trying to be a Linux troll, but I'm running Firefox (23 tabs), Gaim, a terminal, my mail client, Emacs, Blender, and the Gimp on a 1Ghz without lag.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/toughyorp.png[/img]

title: Re: Ksat.
content:
Well, just so I can show off too, I'm running Blender, Azureus, Eclipse (a rather weighty C++ IDE), e-mail, a Jabber IM client, XMMS (a Winamp clone for Linux), and a few GKrellM instances (for monitoring system info across a few PCs.) Not that they take up much, but four terminals, and the one connected to my local PC runs 'screen' with (at the time of writing) 22 shells running in it.

Oh, and three Firefox windows with 58 tabs between them (mostly because I've fallen into the trap of using tabs instead of bookmarks, since I found a plugin to restore all the tabs after a crash/restart/blackout/etc.)

And my CPU is sitting at 2% usage. So you really don't need a powerful CPU just to have a lot of programs running... (mine's an Athlon XP 2800+ for the record.) RAM helps though - I've got ~600MB of RAM in use out of 1GB (mostly because of Firefox and Eclipse.) I do have two monitors though, which really helps to keep things uncluttered...all I need now is a third [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Ksat.
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]And my CPU is sitting at 2% usage. So you really don't need a powerful CPU just to have a lot of programs running... (mine's an Athlon XP 2800+ for the record.) RAM helps though - I've got ~600MB of RAM in use out of 1GB (mostly because of Firefox and Eclipse.) I do have two monitors though, which really helps to keep things uncluttered...all I need now is a third[hr][/quote]
That's true -- most of my programs are just idling and not sucking up CPU time. I think we were using CPU speed as a single number metric for computer power. It's a safe bet that most 2 Ghz machines are beefier than most 1 Ghz machines. I've got around 350 Mb of memory, so all my stuff fits without much swapping. Still, my machine run Linux much more smoothly than it ran Windows, even when Windows had a smaller workload. The family computer is at 2.2 Ghz with 256 Mb of memory and lags horribly.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/toughyorp.png[/img]

title: Re: Ksat.
content:
Man... you suffer; I just put commonly used items into my quicklaunchbar... though I have omni-tasked before, and it crashed the computer, cause:

I was running SpyBot, Microsoft Spyware, Ad-Aware SE, and Norton Internet security scans (All trying to look at different parts of the hard drive)

I was uploading crap to my website, and was editing about 3 term papers at once.

I had the keen clone running, and PCKF, K:M, and a few other website were running, and I was searching my computer for about 5 other things... and then it crashed.

title: Re: Ksat.
content:
"I just put commonly used items into my quicklaunchbar..."

The only problem with that is that you usually have to wait for a second or so while the program loads - if it's already running it's instant [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

"I was running... and then it crashed."

Well I will be a 'Linux troll' and say that if you tried that sort of thing under Linux then the programs accessing the disk would slow down but everything else would continue without a hitch.

My hard drive actually decided to shut itself down the other day (hooray for the Australian summer and no air conditioner), and I didn't notice for a few hours, until I tried to save something and there was nowhere to save it to. You wouldn't catch Windows doing that, it'd blue screen at the first chance it got [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Ksat.
content:
I imagine the cause of the crash was Norton - it runs its scan process at "very high" priority, which means that it is given priority above everything except Windows' underlying processes. As a result, it tends to lock up if you try to anything else at the same time. Had you used a different virus scanner (ie one that doesn't treat your PC as its bitch) then you'd have been fine.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[url=http://www.last.fm/user/grafix5000/][img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img][/url]
